article.title: Balisage authoring stylesheets README

abstract.para: A quick README describing the stylesheets available for authors writing Balisage papers in XML, with how to instructions.

personblurb.para: Wendell Piez has participated in Balisage since its inception in 2008, and in many other XML and markup industry conferences before and since.

article.para: Two XSLT stylesheets are provided in this distribution for the convenience of Balisage authors writing conference papers, along with related materials:

listitem.para: balisage-html.xsl is a plain preview stylesheet generating a simple (HTML) web page suitable for printing. The CSS file balisage-plain.css is referenced by HTML generated by this stylesheet, and should be placed alongside these results.
This stylesheet may be used standalone.

balisage-proceedings-html.xsl generates an HTML version of a paper in the form it will appear in conference proceedings, with Proceedings look and feel. The CSS stylesheet balisage-proceedings.css should be used with its results.

This stylesheet calls in balisage-html.xsl as an imported module, so that the logic used by both stylesheets is consistent. (Only the layout is different.) It will not work if balisage-html.xsl is not also present in the same subdirectory.

It will be a kindness to Balisage not to post on the Internet any XML using this stylesheet or HTML generated from it. In order to avoid brand confusion, please use the plain preview stylesheet instead, or a variant you create for yourself.

In addition, the CSS stylesheet balisage-author.css is provided, to apply directly to a Balisage paper, for use (for example) in structured editors. It is standard CSS and should work in a variety of tools, with minimal modification or tuning. (It has been tested in oXygen 11.2).

This stylesheet calls in an additional CSS stylesheet, docbook-table.css, to handle table formatting. Even without this module, it should degrade gracefully (although of course tables will not be supported as fully).

section.title: In a browser
section.para: Web browsers now supporting XSLT 1.0 transformations include Mozilla/Firefox, MS Internet Explorer, Apple Safari, Opera, and others. Browsers generally support a standard binding mechanism between an XML document and a stylesheet, in this form:<?xml-stylesheet type="text/xsl" href="balisage-html.xsl"?>Place this code (referencing the stylesheet you want) at the top of your document, and open it in your browser. (Note that some browsers require the stylesheet to be in the same subdirectory as the document, out of security concerns.)

When using a browser to transform your XML directly, CSS stylesheet(s) and icons should be in the same subdirectory as the (XML source) document, and images called by the document should be positioned correctly relative to it.

section.title: In a standalone processor
section.para: The stylesheets use standard XSLT 1.0, so any conformant XSLT 1.0 processor can convert XML valid to the Balisage 1.2 DTD (or to RNG or XSD variants thereof) into HTML. Configuration will depend on your tool.

After running a transformation and writing (serializing) the HTML results to a file, be sure that CSS stylesheets and icons needed for the display are placed in the same subdirectory as the HTML file, and that any images called by the file are positioned correctly relative to it.

section.title: How to use the CSS
section.para: To achieve formatted display in a structured XML editor such as oXygen, XMetaL or XMLMind, use the balisage-author.css stylesheet provided here, binding it with a similar processing instruction at the top of your XML document:<?xml-stylesheet type="text/css" href="balisage-author.xsl"?>

Note that depending on your authoring environment's support of CSS, you may have variable results. Consult your product documentation, or compare this CSS directly with CSS known to work in your tool, if you find adjustments need to be made.

section.title: Examples
section.para: This README document is an example of a valid Balisage paper with its stylesheet linked: open it in a browser and see (if you haven't already). As distributed, it calls in the plain preview stylesheet.
In addition, a mockup of a Balisage paper, TagZoo.xml, calls the Proceedings stylesheet.

In both documents, the DOCTYPE declaration has been commented out to facilitate processing in uncontrolled environments; to validate either, correct and uncomment its declaration, or include another schema binding.
